choices.E: INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns only support monthly intervals within a range of years.
choices.C: INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns support yearly intervals.
choices.F: The value in an INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND column can be copied into an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH column.
choices.A: INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns only support monthly intervals within a single year.
choices.B: INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND columns support fractions of seconds.
choices.D: The YEAR field in an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH column must be a positive value.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
BC is correct

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about INTERVAL data types?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Answer are A & E.

choices.B: The data dictionary does not store metadata in tables.
choices.C: Views with the prefix ALL_, DBA_ and USER_ are not all available for every type of metadata.
choices.A: The data dictionary is accessible when the database is closed.
choices.D: Views with the prefix DBA_ display only metadata for objects in the SYS schema.
choices.E: Views with the prefix ALL_ display metadata for objects to which the current user has access.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about the data dictionary?

choices.B:
WHERE (UPPER(cust_last_name) LIKE ‘A%’ OR UPPER(cust_last_name) LIKE ‘B%’)
AND ROUND(cust_credit_limit) < 1000;
choices.C:
WHERE UPPER(cust_last_name) BETWEEN UPPER(‘A%’ AND ‘B%’)
AND ROUND(cust_credit_limit) < 1000;
choices.E:
WHERE (UPPER(cust_last_name) LIKE INITCAP(‘A’) OR UPPER(cust_last_name) LIKE INITCAP(‘B’))
AND ROUND(cust_credit_limit) < ROUND(1000);
choices.D:
WHERE (INITCAP(cust_last_name) LIKE ‘A%’ OR INITCAP(cust_last_name) LIKE ‘B%’)
AND cust_credit_limit < 1000;

questions.question_text:
Examine the description of the CUSTOMERS table:

//IMG//


You need to display last names and credit limits of all customers whose last name starts with A or B in lower or upper case, and whose credit limit is below 1000.
Examine this partial query:

SELECT cust_last_name, cust_credit_limit FROM customers

Which two WHERE conditions give the required result?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
CD is correct

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about substitution variables?

choices.A: A substitution variable can be used only in a SELECT statement.
choices.B: A substitution variable used to prompt for a column name must be enclosed in double quotation marks.
choices.E: A substitution variable prefixed with & always prompts only once for a value in a session.
choices.C: A substitution variable can be used with any clause in a SELECT statement.
choices.D: A substation variable prefixed with && prompts only once for a value in a session unless it is set to undefined in the session.
choices.F: A substitution variable used to prompt for a column name must be enclosed in single quotation marks.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
AB is the correct answer

comments.content:
You can't corralate scalar subquery expression with outer query. This is the point. Main difference between scalar subquery expression and corraleted subquery expression is that the first one can't be join. If you join scalar subquery expression automaticly it changes in corraleted subquery expression.
Correct: A,B.

Surely you can correlate, the alternative says you CANT, correlate is not only JOIN
select * from employees e 
where maximum_permitted_absence < (select sum(days_absent) from absences a where a.emp_id = e.emp_id)

questions.question_text: Which two are true about scalar subquery expressions?

choices.A: They can return at most one row.
choices.E: You can use them as a default value for a column.
choices.B: You must enclose them in parentheses.
choices.C: You cannot correlate them with a table in the parent statement.
